Prisoner's Defence. I worked at the same bench with the prosecutor; he borrowed tools of me, and lent me tools; when he has been up to the build
ing he has taken my tools without my sanction; a little before Christmas the master was very short of paying, and one Saturday night he had no wages for me; the prosecutor was using my jack-plane; I said I must pawn it; he said he should want it to-morrow, and I might take the other things, and leave the plane for him.

JOSBPH DEAN
re-examined. There was no agreement of that kind—he had no tools scarcely—I knew nothing of his pawning these—I have lost 3l.; or 4l.; worth of tools—the prisoner left his work half finished, and Mr. Newman lost a cramp worth 2l.; 19s.

GUILTY . Aged 49.—
Confined Six Months

725.
WILLIAM CHURCHILL was indicted
for stealing 22 black pud
dings, value 1s. 10d.; the goods of William Gunston.
CHARLES LOADER . I am in the service of William Gunston. On the 2nd of Feb. I was coming home, and saw the prisoner take twenty-two black
puddings from the window, put them under his apron, and walk away—I pursued, and he threw them out of his apron—they were my master's.
Prisoner's Defence. A man dropped them, I did not take them.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Two Months.

726.
FRANCIS EYRES was indicted
for stealing 1 cloak, value 1l.; the goods of
Elizabeth Mabon; and that he bad been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH MABON . I am a widow, and live in Seymour-place. I went to the prisoner's sister's house, on the 27th of Jan., and hung my cloak behind the door—I was there from ten o'clock in the morning till half-past nine at night—I then missed it—I went and told the prisoner's uncle and aunt of it—this is it.
WILLIAM CRUSH . I am a pawnbroker. This cloak was pawned by the prisoner on the evening of the 27th of Jan.—he said it was his wife's.
Prisoner. It was from distress; I was out of work three months.
JOSEPH NIFTON (police-constable D 118.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read.)
JOHN LIOMIN . I was at the trial—the prisoner is the person then tried.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

727.
THOMAS SEXTON was indicted
for stealing 2 1/2 lbs. weight of brass, value 2s., 6d.; and 1 metal pillar, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
William M'Do
nald; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM M'DONALD . I keep a broker's shop, in Great Wild-street. On the 1st of Feb. I placed a metal gas-pillar outside my door—it was two feet six inches from the pavement, and tied with a string—I missed it—the po
liceman brought it to me—this is it.

ROBERT ADAMS (police-constable E 109.) I saw the prisoner with this pillar, in Belton-street, Long-acre, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, on the 1st of February—he said he picked it up in Long-acre—he might be about 500 yards from the prosecutor's.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.
CHARLES GRAHAM (police-constable S 21.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

728.
HENRY FRANCIS was indicted
for stealing 1 bag, value 1s.; 14lbs. weight of tobacco, 2l.; 2s. 8d.; 1lb. weight of cheroots, 9s.; and 2lbs. weight of cigars, 13s.; the goods of
Henry White and another.

GEORGE WATTS . I am warehouseman to Henry and John White—I sent a bag out with 14lbs. of tobacco, and these other things, on the 2nd of Feb., by Meadows the carman—this is the bag and the articles—they are my master's.
ELEAZOR MEADOWS . I put this bag into the cart—I was in Whitechapel—a woman ran and told me the bag was gone—I looked at the tail of the cart, and missed it—this is it.
Prisoner. Q. How far had you got from Osborn-street? A. Perhaps 200 yards.
THOMAS COCKRAN (Police-constable H 143.) I saw the prisoner running with this bag—when he got within ten yards of me he dropped it.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not fall over the curb-stone? A. No, you did not.

WM. COLMAN (police-sergeant H 2.) I was outside the Police-court when the prisoner was brought in—he said in a spontaneous sort of manner, "I am sorry that I have done this act—if I get over it I will take care it shall be the last thing I will ever touch."

Prisoner's Defence. The words I spoke were, I was very sorry I was in the street, and that I interfered with picking it up, or going near the police-man; I was in Osborne-street; I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw some person run from the tail of the cart, and drop a parcel; I took it up, and, seeing the policeman, I was going to give it him, but I tripped against the—curb and dropped it; he cried out "Stop thief;" I got up and ran—two policemen let the other person run up Wentworth—street, and they took me.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.

729.
PETER BROWN and
MICHAEL BARRY were indicted for
stealing 1 jar, value 2s. and 3/4 lb. weight of tobacco, value 3s., the goods of
William Ballinger.

MARY HOWARD . I am servant to Mr. William Ballinger. On the 4th of Feb., at night, I was in the back parlour— I saw brown come into the shop,take a jar of tobacco, and go out to the step of the door, and hand it to Barry— I am sure he is the person— I gave information and went and caught Brown, but I did not get the jar— Barry handed it away to two accomplices.

Cross examined by Mr Horry Q. How far did Barry go with it? A. A little way, and then handed it to two other boys — Brown would have run away, but i caught hold of him, and my mistress came out— Barry crossed the road, then came back and stood there, and when the policeman came up I gave him into custody.

Brown I went past the prosecutor's shop, and a man said, "What have you got?" I said, "Nothing;" the woman then came out, and said "This is one;" she told the man to hold me; she swore that all she knew me by was my blue jacket and white trowsers; I said I had not white trowsers, but fustian; she said, "Whether or not, it is you;" I am quite a stranger to this boy.
JOHN SHEARER (police constable H 154) I took Brown to the shop, and took Barry afterwards— I have known them both for eight or nine monthss— I have seen them more than once together.

Cross-examined Q. Upon your solemn oath have you seen them together eight months ago? A. I have seen them from one to nine months ago, in WHitechapel-road and about—Barry lives in Spring-gardens, Whitechapel.

BROWN*—
GUILTY Aged 17

BARRY*—
GUILTY Aged 17

730.
ANN HART and
ELIZA LLOYD were indicted
for stealing 3 jugs, value 2 s, the goods of
John West.
ELIZA MILLICHAMP I am the wife of Thomas Millichamp. My brother, John West, keeps a china-shop— I missed a set of three jugs from his door last Monday—they were like those produced.

EDWARD BUROESS (police-constable H 198.) I saw the prisoners standing at Mr. West's door at a quarter before eight o'clock—I saw Hart take these jugs and hand them to Lloyd—I followed and took them with them—I was ten or twelve yards from them

HART—
GUILTY . Aged 22

LLOYD—
GUILTY . Aged 22

731.
WILLIAM LAWSON was indicted
for stealing 2 shirts, value 8s.; and one shift, value 2s., the goods of
James Brown

LYDIA BROWN. I am the wife of James Brown. I hung out two shirts and a shift to dry on the 1st of Feb., about a quarter to six o'clock in the evening—I missed them directly, and followed the prisoner out of my place.

WILLIAM HENRY BROWN . On Thursday evening, the 1st of Feb. my mother was running after the prisoner—I ran too—there was another with the prisoner—the prisoner had a bundle, and he threw it to the other boy, who ran away—I saw the prisoner come out of our premises and turn the corner.

JOHN HAWKSWORTH . I h eard a cry of "Stop thief"—I saw the prisoner running up the lane—he threw what looked to me like a bundle of clothes to another boy, and said, "Cut away, Bill, across to the Britannia."

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Months.

732.
WILLIAM HARRIS was indicted
for feloniously receiving 9 yards of lace, value 24l.;, the goods of
James Marshall and another, well knowing them to have been stolen.

JOHN SNELLGROVE . I am assistant to James Marshall and Co., of vere-street, Oxford-street—on the 31st of Jan. Williams produced these nine yards of lace to me amongst others for sale—I am quite certain it is my employer's—it is a very beautiful piece—it is the length of our piece, and the colour and pattern—I am quite certain it had not been sold.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How many persons are in your master's service? A. From fourteen to sixteen—I have not sold this, and it is not entered in the books—the books are not here—I buy all the lace goods—I did not miss this till it was offered for sale—I only know of this lace by examining the books and the lace-box.
NOT GUILTY .

733.
THOMAS ROSKILLY was indicted
for stealing 2 yards of cloth, value 1l.; 3s., and 1 1/2 yard of velvet, 13s., the goods of
Edward Grove, his master.

STEPHEN GROVE . I act for my brother, Edward Grove, who is a tailor—the prisoner was in his employ—on the 30th of Jan. he ordered the prisoner to cut some cloth for a coat off a piece which contained 22 1/2 yards—the coat would take two yards—I measured the cloth after he had cut it, and there were but 18 1/2 yards—there were two yards gone—it was found inside the prisoner's trowsers.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

734.
RICHARD ANDS and
THOMAS BROWN were indicted for
stealing 2 coats, value 3l.;, the goods of
John Wills; and that Brown had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES POLLOCK . I am shopman to John Wills, of Oxford-street—between lix and seven o'clock in the evening, on the 24th of Jan., I was in the shop—I received information, ran to the corner of Berwick-street, and saw Brown running with a coat—he was brought back with it—when I returned I missed that coat and another, which I had seen safe two minutes before—I did not see any other person but Brown—he was about a dozen yards from our house when I saw him.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Who brought the coat back? A. The person who took Brown—I lost sight of Brown when I returned to the shop.

EDWARD POWLES . I was in the prosecutor's shop that evening—I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I ran out and picked up one coat at the corner of Berwick-street—I saw Brown brought back in about three minutes by a gentleman who stopped him, and he had another coat.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not see Brown stopped? A. Yes, when I
had picked up the coat I ran after him—a gentleman stopped him about twenty yards down Berwick-street; and when I got up to him the gentleman had the coat which I had seen Brown with.

ALFRED HAYWARD . I was just coming out of our house, and saw Brown running in a very great hurry—he had hardly put his foot on the step of our door when a gentleman stopped him, and took him back to the prosecutor.

Cross-examined. Q. Had Brown any thing with him? A. I did not notice it—he was going into a house, and a gentleman stopped him—I do not think a person twelve yards up the street could have seen him laid hold of—I never saw the coat in our shop—if it had been dropped in the shop I must have seen it.

EDWARD POWLES
re-examined. The gentleman stopped Brown twenty or twenty-five yards up Berwick-street—I do not know that he went into Hay ward's shop—he must have run in there before he was caught, if he did go in—I am sure Brown had the coat before the gentleman had it.

BARNARD THOMAS ASH (police-constable A 62). I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw Ands running down Wardour-street—I took him back to the prosecutor, and he was identified as having been near there previously.
BENJAMIN ADDIS (policeman.) I was at the corner of Poland-street a little after six o'clock, and saw the two prisoners pass me together.
NATHAN JARVIS (police-constable E 41.) I produce a certificate of Brown's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

ANDS—
NOT GUILTY .

735.
JOSEPH DORMAN was indicted
for stealing 24 printed books, value 16s., the goods of
Charles Daly.

CHARLES DALY . I live in Greville-street, Hatton-garden. I was returning home about ten o'clock, on the 31st of Jan., and saw marks of feet in my hall—I thought some of my people wanted me, and I said, "I am here"—the prisoner then came out, and went past me—I thought it strange, I ran and caught him, and said, "You have been robbing my house"—he was stronger than I, and would have got away, but a neighbour came up—we got him back, and found these books on him, which are mine
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

736.
ISAAC BAKER was indicted
for stealing 1 horse-cloth, value 5s., the goods of
Robert Skiggs.

JOHN MASON . I am carman to Mr. Robert Skiggs, and live in Essex. On the 6th of Feb. my wagon was in Brown's-lane, Spitalfields—I missed a cloth off my horse—I went up to the prisoner's cart, and found it on his cart—he said he did not take it from the horse—he went away, and left his cart with me.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. He came back? A. Yes, in about twenty minutes—when I said to him, "You have taken my cloth," he denied it—I went round his cart, and saw a piece of my cloth hanging from his cart—I took it, and said, "This is my cloth"—he did not say he must have dropped his own cloth—I do not think he had a cloth on his horse—my cloth had not been fastened on my horse—when he came back to me in about twenty minutes, he wanted to know where his cart was—I told him it was gone to the green-yard—I had before called a policeman—I gave him into custody.
GEORGE HUNT (police-constable H 135.) When I came back from the green-yard the prisoner was at the station—his horse had a sort of leather
round his loins, but the prosecutor's other horses had cloths on them, much the same as this—I did not see any cloth on the prisoner's cart.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
737.
JAMES MOODY was indicted
for stealing 1 stove, value 7s., the goods of
Thomas Freeman, and fixed to a building.—2nd COUNT, not stating it to be fixed; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Confined Two Months.

738.
JOHN LONGHURST was indicted
for stealing 70lbs. weight of lead, value 1l.;, the goods of
William Austin, and fixed to a building; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

739.
DANIEL COLLINS was indicted
for stealing 1 shovel, value 3s. 3d., the goods of
William Noble; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Fourteen Days.

740.
WILLIAM PRATT was indicted
for stealing one gown, value 5s.; 1 frock, 5s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 2s.; 1 night-gown, 2s.; and 2 yards of ca
lico, 1s.; the goods of
Charles Sinclair Puckett.

SARAH PUCKETT . I am the wife of Charles Sinclair Puckett, of Rosoman-street, Clerkenwell. On Saturday evening, the 3rd of Feb., I went with my child into the parlour, with a lighted candle, and saw the prisoner standing by the side of the fire-place—I saw his face—he asked if Crawford was there—I screamed out, and he got out of the parlour-door—I followed him to the street-door—it was three or four yards from where he passed me, to the street-door—I had my candle in one hand, and the child in the other—the street-door was shut—he opened it after about two minutes—he was feeling up above the lock—I screamed, and put the candle in his face, which put it out—he escaped—I called "Stop thief," but did not go after him—he jumped off my step into the road, and went towards Lower Rosoman-street—he was brought back by a policeman and the person next door—I saw a black mark on his face, about an inch long, like the snuff of a candle—some one said they thought he got in over the area—he said he had not been there before at all—when he was brought back I missed a silk frock off the screen in the par
lour—I afterwards missed a pair of trowsers and a piece of calico from the back parlour—they were in a bundle which bad not been there before—they were safe half an hour before—when the policeman brought him back, he said, "Please don't give me in charge"—I found some matches in both rooms, and in the front parlour burnt matches, which had been struck, but not lighted—these are the things—they are ours.

CHARLES FLURDELL . I work in Upper Rosoman-street, next door to the prosecutor. I heard the cry of "Stop thief," and ran out at the street door—I saw the prisoner jump off the steps of the prosecutor's house on to the pavement—I ran after him—he ran nine or ten yards, then fell, and knocked an old lady down at the corner of Rosoman-street—I caught him in Whiskin-street—he said he was not the man—I said I would believe my own eyesight before any one—I did not lose sight of him—I was not above two ox three yards from him the whole time.
SETH BULL (policeman.) I took the prisoner—he said he was not in the street, but I saw him running.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going to the Angel; I was not in the street at all; I heard the cry; a young man ran by me, and down a court.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

741.
WILLIAM JEFFRIES was indicted
for stealing 6 sheets of printed paper, value 2d.; 7 sheets of paper, 2d.; 23 printed books, 2s.; half-a-pint of ink, 6d.; 4 hanks of twine, 6d.; 2 packets of stove-paste, 1s.; 2 boxes of tooth-powder, 6d.; and 5 book-binders' tools, called letters, value 6s.; the goods of
George John Ford, his master.

GEORGE JOHN FORD , printer, Beech-street. The prisoner came into my service as shopman six or seven months ago—he continued till this day-week—having missed various kinds of property, I put myself in communica
tion with the police—I know these bookbinders' tools—this sheet of paper is printed for the express use of our office, and is of no use to any one else—it is used to find out the type, and no one else has any right to it—I know it by the impression of my own type on it—these small books were printed at our office—I know them by the type, and by the matter of them—here are fourteen—" The Way to Wealth," and "Advice to a Young Tradesman," by Franklin; and some of Pinnock's Catechisms—I know them by the dirt on them, and being in the office for a length of time—I never sold them—the prisoner had no right to take them—this is my bodkin, and is used in print
ing—he had no right to take it—here are some tools, called bookbinders' letters, belonging to a set—they are mine—here are two bottles of ink, which I know, and some twine, which was used in our business, and two packets of stove-paste—they are mine, and correspond in quality with what I missed—the paper I know from the soil, and from the damp; and two boxes of tooth
powder—I can speak to them all—I believe them to be mine—the whole are worth 10s.—here are seven sheets of paper, such as we had.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRT. Q. Are you a master printer? A. Yes—some of these books bear my name—I am the publisher—we sell them in the trade at the rate of 9d. a dozen—they have been printed, and have ben on sale some years—" The Way to Wealth" was never sold, because it was never pushed in the trade—I do not recollect selling any, except a few copies—I have never bought any of them—they have been in the trade—this other is the "Paraclete"—there were more of them sold—the other works were not printed by me—they are various sorts of religious tracts—I saw these only I few months since—this one is an odd number—this book, "Idle Jack Brown," was one of a set in the printing-office, and I missed it—the last time I recollect seeing it, was four or five months ago—I have four apprentices, two of them come from the parish—I have given the whole four a month's imprisonment for robbing me—Franklin is one of them—he is in my service now—I did not talk to him about being robbed—he came to me with another apprentice, and told me—he came and asked me to take him back, and it was in consequence of his communication, and promising to act properly, that I agreed to take him back—the prisoner has done work for my father and me—here are three impressions of this pattern paper found—I had a number thrown off—Franklin told me he was told by the prisoner to say that I fed him badly—he has complained about it—I fed him properly—I complained of his stopping away and neglecting his duty—there is nothing particular about the two bottles of ink—I know them—there is a label on the bottle, which was printed at our office—these tools and bodkin are like other tools used in the trade.
MR. DOANE. Q. Did you sell your own tools to the prisoner? A. No.

JOHN BENJAMIN FRANKLIN . I am thirteen years old, and am apprenticed to the prosecutor—I have been so nearly four years. The prisoner came into his employ about seven months ago—I have fellow-apprentices—about.

eleven months ago we began making free with my matter's property—we went on when the prisoner was there—when he found us out he began-the same himself—Itook three quires of writing-paper out of the drawer, and gave it to him—he buttoned it up in his coat, and took it home—he knew it to be master's—he had some ink—he put the bottles into his pocket, and some stone-blue—I saw some books—I was up in the loop-hole of the office, cleaning it—I put the books out—the prisoner took them, and said they would do for him—he put them into his coat pocket, and took them away the same morning—I know these tools and letters—I did not know he had them—when he took them, I cannot tell—we used to steal every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday—he used to come in the morning and say, "I shall want some more of that paper I had before"—I had a month's imprisonment—my master took me back as I promised to be a good boy, and tell the truth.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the writing-paper the first thing you saw hint take? A. Yes—it is not here—the ink was the next thing—I oasnot say whether be took anything more that morning—the books were taken on quite's different day—I cannot say whether this box was taken on a different day to the ink and paper—there was ink, stone-blue, and paper take—I think the writing-paper and ink were taken at the same time, and the books were-all taken together—he took paper at different times—the prosecutor found out that we were robbing, but did not complain to us—I do not think he stopped me once when I was going to take something out—I cannot say whether he did or not—I do not think I begged forgiveness of him—I cannot recollect bis stopping and talking to me about wasting my master's property—it may. have happened—I used to threaten to tell Mr. Ford of this, and Jem used to knock me about—I might have taken some books—I took a good many things—I told Mr. Ford every thing I took—I have never taken any books like these—I used to give all the paper and things that I took to Mr. Wright—he used to promise us things, and used to give us money—when the prisoner heard that we were taken, he got from my master's wife where we were taken to—he got home as soon as he could, and got all the things that were my master's as soon as be could, out of his house, because he waa frightened that we should tell.
MR. DOANE. Q. When he stopped you thieving, did you go and tell your master? A. No.

STEPHEN MANSFIELD (police-constable N 233.) I went to the prisoner's lodging, in Gray's Inn-lane, last Monday evening—I found him there, and told him I took him for robbing Mr. Ford—he said there was nothing there belonging to Mr. Ford, and we were at liberty to search—I searched, and found a basket by the side of his bed, and, in the basket, the property I have produced to-night—he said, the small books he bought at stalls, and the reft were Mr. Ford's
Cross-examined. Q. Upon your oath, were not the words he laid, that the small books he bought, and none of the others belonged to Mr. Ford? A. No
NOT GUILTY .

742.
WILLIAM ALEXANDER MEREDITH was indicted
for stealing 1 violoncello, value 8l.; 8s.; the goods of
Thomas Sale Barling.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

743.
PHCEBE LOUISA FELLS and
EMMA DRIVER were indicted for
stealing 1 child's robe, value 5s. 6d.; the goods of
Charles Willett .
CHARLES WILLETT , laceman, High-street, whitechapel. On the night of

the 6th of Feb. I was leaving my shop to go out—I saw Driver and another person, (I cannot say whether it was Fells,) standing together close to my window—there had been a pane of glass broken at the corner, and a nail and a card at the window—it was quite sound as I put it—when I came out, I went away a little while—when I came back I found the card broken and pushed in, and the window broken more—I missed a muslin robe—when I went out it was safe in the window opposite the broken glass—I received information, and went after the girls—I saw two policemen, and then went to Mr. Barr's, the pawnbroker, and there found the prisoners in custody—the pawnbroker brought the robe to me—I know it by a private mark.

THOMAS DICKER , shopman to John Barr, pawnbroker, Osbom-street, White-chapel. About seven o'clock in the evening of the 6th of Feb., the prosecutor came into the shop and gave information—about ten minutes after, the prisoners came in together with this robe—Fells asked me to lend her 4s. on it—I kept the robe and them too, and when Mr. Willett came again, he found them in my custody.
EDWARD BURGESS (police-constable H 198.) I took the prisoners—Fells told me it had been given her to pawn by a tall woman

Fell's Defence. A woman tapped me on the shoulder, and asked me to take this frock in to pawn; she told me, if the pawnbroker asked me any questions, to say my mother sent me, and to pawn it in my own name.

FELLS*—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

DRIVER—
GUILTY . Aged 18—
Confined One Month.

744.
CHARLES TREVIS was indicted
for stealing 6 yards of canvas, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 sack, 6d., the goods of
Richard Collett; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

RICHARD COLLETT . I keep a beer-shop, in Barrett-grove, Stoke Newing
ton. This piece of canvas and sack are mine—they were in a stable—I saw them safe about a fortnight ago—I lost them last Monday morning—I had frequently seen the prisoner about my place.

THOMAS WILLIAM TRAVERS , marine store-dealer, Kingsland. On Mon
day the 5th Feb. the prisoner brought this piece of canvas and two sacks to sell—I had a suspicion and gave him into custody.
JAMES PLAYFORD (policeman.) The prisoner was given into my custody—I got both the sacks and canvas.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the sacks on the dust hill, at Mr. Newman's, Ball's Pond, opposite the new market.

WILLIAM STRANKS (police-constable N 27) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Sessions House, Clerken
well—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY —
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

745.
SAMUEL GABRIEL was indicted
for stealing 10 brushes, the goods of
Rachael Robinson.

RACHAEL ROBINSON . I am a widow, and keep an oil shop in Brick-lane, Beth
nal-green. About seven o'clock in the evening of the 8th Feb. these scrubbing brushes hung on a nail on my door post—about an hour after the policeman came and asked me if I had lost anything, and I missed these ten brushes.

JOHN HOPE (police-constable H 122.) About seven o'clock in the evening of the 8th of Feb. I met the prisoner in Bethnal-green-road with a bundle—I asked what was in it—he would not give me any answer—I found they were brushes—I asked where he got them—he said he bought them on the road—I went to the prosecutrix, and she owned them.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the lane, a person asked me to buy the Brushes, and I did.

GUILTY .* Aged 16.—
Confined Two Months.

745.
SARAH PERRY was indicted
for stealing 2 boots, value 2s. the goods of
George Underwood.

GEORGE UNDERWOOD . I live with my father, George Underwood, a boot and shoe maker, in Chapel-street, Somers-town. About nine o'clock in the evening of the 6th Feb. the prisoner came and asked the price of a pair of shoes in the window—I told her, and she went away—she came again in custody of the constable, who had these two odd boots, which are my father's—I had seen them safe on the window about ten minutes before.

THOMAS MORTON (police-constable S 1.) About nine o'clock on this evening I saw the prisoner walking very fast in Chapel-street—a person was in pursuit of her—I stopped her—the person was accusing her of stealing a kettle—I found these boots under her arm—she said, "They are mine"—I took her down to the prosecutor's shop, and he identified them.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming through Chapel-street, and these two odd shoes laid apart, I picked them up.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Two Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
746.
THOMAS SARGEANT was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, 3 crowns, 6 half-crowns, 14 shillings, 2 sixpences, 30 four penny pieces, 30 pence, and 16 halfpence, the monies of
Francis Tucker and others, his masters.

JOHN MURRELL . I am porter to Francis Tucker and two others, of South Moulton-street. In consequence of observations I made of the shop cash, during Aug. and Sept., I made a communication to my employers—I after
wards observed the entries made in the cash-book—I took particular observa
tion of the dripping and other stuff that was purchased during the 9th of Sept., 1843—on that day John Tarrant, who is usually in the shop, went to Gravesend—I remained there besides the prisoner—we were the only persons in the shop—at two o'clock the prisoner went to dinner—I looked at the drip
ping and the change—the dripping is kept in a large tab in the cellar, and the change on a board about three feet by two and a half—the tub would contain about three hundredweight of dripping or a little more—I took the trowel which is usually kept in the cellar and smoothed the surface of the dripping in the tub, and I made a cross on it all the way across the tub—I then examined the changes on the board—there was about two stone of it, just sufficient to cover the board—I returned to the shop and looked into the drawer which is used for the reception of dripping in the shop, before it is taken down to the tub in the cellar—I found the drawer quite empty—I have the shop cash-book here—it was the prisoner's duty to purchase dripping and articles of that description in the shop, and enter them in the book—while he was out that day I examined this cash-book—I found the last entry was two stone of changes, by which it appears that they had been delivered before he went to dinner, and there was about two stone of changes on the board or dresser—on the prisoner's return about three, I left the shop—I returned a little after four—I

then looked at the shop cash-book and found an entry of thirty-seven pounds of dripping, 9s. 3d., and two stone four pounds of changes 5s. 5d., making together 14s. 8d.—I went in the cellar and examined the tub, and found there had been no dripping whatever added to it—I looked in the drip
ping drawer, and none had been put in there—I looked at the dresser, where the changes were kept, and none had been added there—the cross which I had made on the dripping in the tub was quite visible, and if thirty-seven pounds had been added to it that would not have been the case—on the 25th of Sept. Tarrant returned from Gravesend and I made a communication to him on this subject—here is the shop cash-book—it is balanced on the 8th of Sept., and the balance carried forward in Tarrant's writing—he went to Gravesend about twelve o'clock, and on that morning this book came into the prisoner's possession—he had to examine it and see that the cash corresponded with the entries—he balanced it on the evening of the 9th, and the balance is 4 1/2 d. over in the till, which will often occur—the balance brought forward is 78l.; 19s. 8d.—it was the prisoner's duty to pay for changes and dripping out of the shop-till.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. I warrant, as soon as you made this discovery on thr 9th, you went to your master? A. I did not say a word about it till my brother shopman came back—I do not know how much money, per month, would pass through the prisoner's hands—it might be 7000l.; or 8000l.;—there was only one receptacle for dripping in use at that time, be
sides the drawer—we have several tubs which are used at different times.

Q. Would not the prisoner frequently purchase in the morning and not enter them till the evening? A. It is not a usual thing—I have frequently seen him purchase dripping—I do not swear that on every occasion he has entered it—I do not know that he has not done so—I have not made any mistakes—I know Mr. Clarkson—I believe he keeps a little shop in Ebury-row—I do not remember his borrowing three papers of Palmer's wicks from our house—he frequently borrows them—I do not remember his borrowing three pupen of Palmer's wicks—I did not go to Mrs. Clarkson and tell her that I had for
gotten to enter three pounds of metallic wicks, and ask her what I should do, nor did I say, "You must not let our people know it, for if you do, Sargeant will find it out and kick up the d—I's own row about it"—I will swear there was not an omission of entering three pounds of Palmer's candles—the prisoner has never found fault with my conduct—there might be a few little words perhaps—I do not remember omitting to enter some goods purchased by Mrs. Clark
son, on the 24th of Dec.—I will not swear I did not omit it—I do not remem
ber an entry that should have been made on the 27th of Jan. that was not in
serted till Feb.—I swear that was not the case—I never make entries in the book—I make them on a slip of paper—I have on every occasion made that entry at the time the sale took place—I never failed to do so—I am porter to the prosecutors—it might be the case sometimes, that when goods were de
livered at our house, instead of paying for them at the time, a ticket was given to the person who left them, and they would come some days after and receive the money; but that would be entered on the day on which the goods were bought, not on the day on which the cash was paid—I am certain of that, be
cause there is always a ticket left in the till, and that is brought in as the money paid out—it stands as cash in the book—when the cash is paid the ticket is then destroyed—I know that to be invariably the case—I have seen it done—I do not keep the books.

JURY. Q. Do you take the cash out for that ticket? A. Yes, and it is put in a piece of paper with the ticket—I think there is one family that sell their own dripping and wax ends instead of allowing it to their servant

the dripping and wax ends come from Lord Liverpool's house to our house for sale—I do not know what his lordship does—other noblemen and gentle
men send their dripping and wax ends—I do not know whether it is the practice of our house to allow the house-steward or the principal servant 1d. a pound on every article brought—there is a perquisite allowed—I do not know whether that 1d. a pound would be put down as a separate item—the prisoner's department was in the counting-house—he did not usually attend the shop, only when other people were absent, but he might come into the shop—I do not know who has got the prisoner's place, or whether it is settled—my wages were raised about five weeks ago, or a little more—it was since this affair.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you look at all the tubs in which dripping was usually put? A. Yes, and I examined them all on my return—these tickets are given by the person in charge of the shop at the time, to those who bring the goods instead of cash, as perhaps we might not have change at the time—there was no deficiency of cash on the 9th of Sept.—if any of these tickets had been given after twelve o'clock that day, the money would appear among the cash—one ticket is given to the person, and one is put into the till, and in the evening, when we have sufficient change, the money is rolled up in the paper for the persons when they come for it—I am a yearly servant, and am paid quarterly—my wages have been raised from the 1st of Jan.—they were 16l.; a-year, and are now 18l.;
JURY. Q. Did you when you returned examine all the tubs? A. Yes—there was only one that had dripping in—I looked into the others, and none of them had any.

JOHN TABRANT . I am shopman to Messrs. Tucker and Co. I went to Gravesend on the 9th of Sept., about twelve o'clock—on the evening of the 8th I balanced the cash-book—I returned on the 25th, and on that evening Murrell made a communication to me, and on the 26th I communicated with one of the partners—the money in the till on the evening of the 8th corre
sponded with the cash-book, when I balanced it.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not some of the nobility and gentry keep an account at your house for dripping and wax ends? A. Yes—I do not know that the servants are allowed 1d. a pound on dripping or wax ends brought to our house—if we buy the wax ends of servants, of course we give them the money—there is something allowed to the servant for himself—it is entered in the book as for goods bought—I have never seen the prisoner make entries in the evening, of goods that he had purchased in the morning—I will swear that he has never done so—I go to dinner at one o'clock, and to tea at five—I sometimes go to the Bank, and sometimes to collect money—I am perhaps absent two hours—the prisoner has found fault with me for what he said Was negligence—he has reprimanded me for neglect in making entries in the book—I am Mrs. Tucker's nephew—I remember some time ago omitting to enter 721bs. of candles sold to Messrs. Ferguson and Co., of Ox
ford-street, and some sold to Watkins'—I do not remember omitting to enter goods sold to Hughes, in May Fair.

Q. Do you remember receiving goods from Mr. Clarkson that you did not enter till some days after, when the mistake was discovered? A. I do not know whether I omitted it, the porter might have done so as well as myself—when Clarkson brought his invoice, he said there was something omitted, and I entered it then, and he paid the money to me—it does sometimes happen that parties deliver dripping and wax ends, and receive a ticket for them and do not get the money for several days—in that case the ticket is put by, and entered in the book on the day the money is paid sometimes, and sometimes not.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You said something about servants, what is that? A. The wax ends are considered the perquisite of the butler or footman, and when they bring them we give them less than we do to a collector, but what
ever we receive from a collector, or from a servant, we make an entry in the book of it, so that the book shows everything—there is no separate sum paid to a servant, except for the amount we buy—when the omission which has been asked about occurred, I had not received any money which I had not accounted for, but I had left out an item in the customer's bill, and my omit
ing it caused the prisoner's displeasure.

THOMAS MOSDELL SMITH . I am a partner in the house—Tarrant and Murrell were in our employ—I recollect another servant going to Gravesend, and on that occasion a communication was made to me indirectly by John Tarrant.

Cross-examined. Q. Has it not very often happened that checks have been cashed for your customers, or for neighbours? A. No, it never happened to my knowledge—my department is the superintendence of the cash account and correspondence, not the manufacturing department—our house keeps no account with any nobleman or gentleman for dripping or wax ends, to my knowledge.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What do you mean by saying there is no account with any nobleman or gentleman? A. I know there is one family where the dripping which is supplied by them goes to their credit—in general where there is dripping it goes to the account of the cook.

FREDERICK SHAW (police-sergeant A 29.) I took the prisoner on the 11th of Jan.—I produce a paper which was found by Mr. Smith in the counting-house—it was sealed up—I directed Mr. Smith to break it open.

MR. SMITH re-examined. I found this paper at the bottom of the cash drawer in the iron safe in the counting-house, the name of T. Sergeant is on it—I broke it open—I delivered it to Mr. Blackmore in the same state as it was.
ROBERT BLACKMORE . I am attorney for this prosecution. I received this paper and its contents from Mr. Smith, and delivered it to the officer—it contains a 5l.; note and a sovereign.

ISAAC BLOMFIELD . Iam servant to Mr. Edridge, of Oxford-street. On the 7th of Nov. last I went to the prosecutor's shop, in South Moulton-street—I paid the prisoner, who appeared to be a clerk there, 9l.; 3s. 10d.—part of it was a 5l.; note—this is the note I paid him that day—I know it by the writing on it.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the writing? A. The name of Mr. Fresh
field, 24, Rutland-street, Hampstead-road—when the prosecution was going on they came to my employer, who is a master tallow-chandler, in Oxford-street—(paper read)—"This 6l.; is money over in the shop cash, supposed to belong to T. Serjeant, his own money not being right, and no other account can be given of it; it will be left in the cash drawer, to see if anything else comes to light on the subject. Nov. 4, 1843."

MR. SMITH re-examined. Q. Supposing there was money over or under in the shop cash-book, what was the prisoner's duty? A. To tell me of it—here is the shop cash-book for the 4th of Nov.—here appears to have been 3 1/2 d. over that day—the prisoner never gave me any account of there being 6l.; over in the shop cash.
NOT GUILTY .

747.
THOMAS SARGEANT was again indicted
for stealing 2 sovereigns,3 half-sovereigns, 6 crowns, 12 half-crowns, 29 shillings, 58 sixpences, 85 fourpenny-pieces, 3 pence, and 6 halfpence, the monies of
Francis Tucker and other, his masters.
MESSRS. CLARKSON and BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS MOSDELL SMITH . I am one of the firm of Francis Tucker and others. On Wednesday, the 10th of Jan., in consequence of suspicion, I saw all the sperm and wax ends and scrapings that I had in stock, weighed, about two o'clock—Murrell and Tarrant were in attendance on me in so doing—the weight of the whole was 471lbs. 8ozs., and there appeared by the shop cash-book 13ozs. of scrapings bought that afternoon, which would make the whole weight 472lbs. 5ozs.—I used all the precaution in my power to ascertain the exact quantity—next day, the 11th, about ten ruinates to five o'clock, I gave directions to Shaw, the policeman, and I put three sovereigns and 2l.; worth of shillings, all marked, into the till—there is a well in the till under where the money is kept loose, in which there is a bag with other gold in it—I do not see any entry made in the book by the prisoner on the 10th of Jan.—this entry of 13ozs. is by Tarrant—on the 11th of Jan., about half-past five, I found the prisoner had entered in the shop cash-book as having paid 13lbs. 8ozs. 8 drachms of wax ends 1l.;, 4lbs. of sperm 5s. 3d., and dripping 3s., making in the whole 1l.; 8s. 3d.—I directly called in the policeman, and took him into the counting-house—I called in the prisoner, and said, "Sar
geant, here is an entry I don't exactly understand, when did you buy these things?"—he hesitated, and at length said, "In the morning at eleven o'clock"—I said, "That answer does not satisfy me, I have strong doubts as to your integrity, will you show me the contents of your pockets?"—he threw a lea
thern purse on the desk—I said, "You have more money about you than this"—he then placed his hands in his pocket, and put on the desk a quantity of silver, I believe all in shillings—I found amongst them eight of the shil
lings which I had marked on the Wednesday and put them into the till on the Thursday at ten minutes past five during his absence, and this conversation took place about a quarter before six o'clock—I gave him in charge—I said to him, "To save me the trouble of weighing the stock again, the weight of which I know perfectly well, will you tell me where the things are that you say you bought?"—he replied, "You seem to know all about it; I don't say"—the policeman said, "You need answer no questions, but do you choose to account for having the marked money upon you?"—he replied, "I don't say"—I omitted to state that when I discovered the marked silver amongst his money I could not discover the marked sovereign—I had put three marked sovereigns into the till, and only two of them remained—one of them was gone—I then sent for the bag which was placed in the well of the till, and in that bag I found the marked sovereign—the prisoner was then taken to the station, and I proceeded to weigh the wax ends and other things, and allowing for the 13ozs. being added to it, the real increase was 3ozs., allowing for the turn of the scale—it was quite impossible that I that morning at ten minutes to ten o'clock, and the prisoner was engaged in my presence from about ten minutes to eleven till twenty-five minutes to twelve, and in that time he made no purchase of wax ends, or scrapings, or dripping—he never left the counting-house—I was engaged in an interview with a gentleman in a small place that adjoins the counting-house—while the prisoner was not engaged with me he was with Mr. Harrison in the counting-house—I can un
dertake to say that from ten minutes to eleven till twenty-five minutes to twelve o'clock he-was not out of the counting-house.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. What did you weigh? A. The whole of the wax candle ends, and scrapings, and dripping, on the premises—I weighed the drawers in which they were placed, but I gave the net weight—the tare was marked on the drawers, and the deduction was made—I looked myself into every drawer, to see that there was none but what were weighed—I will not swear as to the number of receptacles the people had, but I will swear there were no more than what were weighed—a regular search was made all over the place, to see that there was no more—I did not weigh anything down stairs—the drawers are the receptacles in the shop, and when they are full they are sent away—there is a cupboard in the shop—I swear that we weighed the whole contents of that—I kept the numeration of the figures—I weighed first at two o'clock, on Wednesday; again, at two o'clock, on Thursday; and again, in the evening after the prisoner was in custody—Murrell and Tarrant were with me every time I weighed it—if the prisoner had told me the drawer in which what he said was bought, was placed, I would have weighed that drawer, but he refused to tell me where the things were—he had not frequent occasions to go to the till where the money was kept—if the porter or shopman were on the premises it was their duty to make those purchases—the prisoner's duty was in the counting-house, not the shop, but, in the absence of the others, it was his duty—we had no scarcity of silver at that time—there was a scarcity, but we had 60l.; or 80l.; worth—I never knew the prisoner to lend to the till, or to borrow of the till—there was plenty in the till.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When you went to the till, after you gave notice to the policeman, did you find the silver you had put there? A. Yes, and on the prisoner I found eight of the marked shillings—there had been no want of silver—I had put entire confidence in the prisoner.

JOHN MURRELL . On the Wednesday, at two o'clock, I attended my master, to weigh all the wax ends and scrapings that there were—they were all brought to the scale on that occasion—Tarrant attended and assisted—I weighed again at two o'clock on Thursday, when all that could be found was again produced—after the prisoner was taken we again weighed them—the weight on all occasions was the same, with the difference of three ounces at 'last—I went to the premises on Thursday morning, the 11th of Jan., at seven o'clock—the prisoner did not sleep on the premises—he came a little afterseven that morning—he was in my sight till eight o'clock, when he went to breakfast—he returned at nine o'clock, and from then till a quarter to twelve he was in my sight—during that time he did not make a purchase of anything, if he had I must have seen it—I was watching for that purpose

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you have various duties to perform? A. I have—I had not occasion to go out from seven to twelve o'clock—I break
fast on the premises—I went to breakfast at the time the prisoner did—I returned in half an hour, and I was there half an hour before he was back—I went out at a quarter to twelve, and returned about half-past twelve—I left the shop after two o'clock in the afternoon—I do not know how many boxes were weighed, but I called the weights out correctly—we weighed the wax, the sperm, the dripping, and every thing we had on the premises—I cannot recollect the number of receptacles there were for the wax ends and dripping.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. There are certain receptacles for wax ends, and scrapings, and sperm? A. Yes, in the shop, and there are others for drip
ping and changes below—we went round, and weighed all that was on the premises—we weighed the dripping also—there were not twelve pounds addi
tion to that—I had marked the dripping-tub with a cross, and that cross was

there the same—it had been arranged that I should not be absent when Tarrant was, nor he be absent when I was—we do not know who the col
lectors are, but if we take any wax ends or scrapings in we know where we put them.

JOHN TARRANT . I was on the premises on the Thursday, from half-past nine till one o'clock, when I went up to dinner—the prisoner could not have purchased wax ends, or dripping, or sperm, that morning, without my seeing him—I had been desired to watch—he purchased no articles that morning—I returned from dinner at half-past one, and then I remained there till five—I might have been absent for two minutes, but he could not have bought any thing in that time—I went out once when Murrell was not there—the pri
soner was in the counting-house when I went out, and he was there when I came back—I balanced the shop cash-book on that Thursday, and it balanced, supposing these goods had been paid for—here is a deduction of 1l.; 8s. 3d., from the shop cash that day by the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you not said, on a former occasion, that you were out from time to time? A. I was not out more than two minutes—I had occasion to go down stairs, but I could hear any one come into the shop, and it is impossible that in that time he could have bought that quantity—I went up stairs once with a letter, but Murrell was in the shop then—I never knew the prisoner borrow money from the till, or lend money to it—I have borrowed money of him when I have not had sufficient change.

JOHN MARKS . I am accountant in the prosecutor's establishment. On the 11th of Jan. I got there about five minutes to ten o'clock—the prisoner was engaged with me the whole morning, except when receiving a small sum of money from Mr. Hall—he made no purchase over the counter—if he had, I think I must have observed it.

FREDERICK SHAW (police-sergeant A 29.) On the 11th of Jan. I went to South Moulton-street, by directions from Mr. Smith—the shopman and porter went away, and during their absence I watched the shop—no person took any thing to sell that day—I saw the prisoner go to the till while no person was in the shop—I crossed the road, and looked through the window—he took something from a bag in the till, and appeared to be counting it—I thought it was money—he had it in his left hand, and was running it over—after that he went into the counting-house—about a quarter of an hour after that Mr. Smith took in the shop cash-book, and he said to the prisoner, "Sergeant, here is an entry I do not understand"—he asked him when these goods had been purchased—the prisoner said, "This morning, at eleven o'clock"—Mr. Smith said, "Why was not the entry made at the time?"—he said he had omitted it—Mr. Smith said, "I don't feel satisfied, I should like to see what you have in your pocket"—he gave him his purse, in which was a check and some money—he then put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out some silver, and amongst it were these eight marked shillings, which I now produce—Mr. Smith asked in what drawer he had placed what he bought—he said he seemed to know all about it, and he did not say.

(William Smart, a coal-merchant; Matthew Bramer, a coal-merchant; Edward Smith, a cheesemonger; Thomas Knight, a butcher; William Howell, a plumber; Charles Meredith, a painter; James Newman, a currier; Thomas Wheeler; David Probert, a carpenter; Ambrose Cook, a tailor; David Bowyer; and John Ingliss, a saddler; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Transported for Seven Years.

774.
JOSEPH KIEWLIEZ was indicted
for stealing 1 ring, value 2l.;, the goods of
Albert Richard Smith, to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

749.
WILLIAM SLOUGH was indicted
for stealing 12 muffineers, value 5l.; 8s.; 2 cruet-frames, 7l.; 16 cruets, 2l.; 3 dishes, 13l.; 1 liquear-frame, 1l.; 3 bottles, 3l.; 1 tureen, 13l.; 1 snuffer-tray mounting, 2s. 2 candlesticks. 3l.; 1 cream-jug, 1l.; 16s.; 1 muffineer-top, 2s.; and 1 pack
ing-case, 5s.; the goods of
Joseph Alexander and another, his masters.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Samuel Roberts and others.—3rd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Frederick Hunt.

WILLIAM SISSONS . I am of the firm of Roberts and Co.—we have a house at Sheffield, and another in the Adelphi. On the night of the 19th of Jan. I filled a chest at Sheffield, and directed it to the Adelphi—it contained the articles stated, worth altogether 53l.; 15s.—it was nailed up, and a printed direction put on it, "S. Roberts, Smith, and Co., Robert-street, Adelphi, London"—the date, "19th of Jan.," and "Carriage paid," put on it—it was delivered to the usual porter, to be forwarded by railway—I have not seen it since.

JOHN TUCKER . I am clerk to Joseph Alexander. It is part of my duty to attend the Birmingham Railway, at Camden-town station, and to receive parcels arriving in London—I have the way-bill of the 22nd of Jan.—there it a box directed to Roberts, Smith, and Co.—I saw it, and the direction on it—it was handed to the van by the prisoner, and it was his duty to deliver it at the direction—there was a boy with him—I did not see the prisoner again till about six o'clock in the evening—he said he had lost the box, or had it stolen in the neighbourhood of Charing-cross—I asked what time—he said be saw it in the van about one, and he missed it between that and three—I said I thought it looked very suspicious, losing it at that hour in the day.
Cross-examined by MR. COBBETT. Q. You have known him some time? A. Yes—he has been in Mr. Alexander's employment many years.

JOSEPH ALEXANDER . I keep the Castle and Falcon, and am agent to the carriers from Sheffield—the prisoner was in my employ to carry parcels—on the evening of the 22nd Jan.; between six and seven o'clock, he came and said he had lost a box for Messrs. Roberts and Co., he did not know how it had gone, that he saw it at Northumberland-house, at one, where he had to deliver goods—that he had to go down to Westminster, and got to the Adelpbi about three—he then looked and missed the box—I asked if he had met any one dur
ing the day—he denied that he had—I then called the boy Simpkins, and questioned him—I then called the prisoner in, and before the prisoner the boy said they met a man named Holmes, in the Hampstead-road, and they went in the public-house and had something to drink, Simpkins standing in the doorway watching the van—that they went to deliver goods—when the bof said they met Holmes, the prisoner said his name was Jesse—Cooper wai sitting in my tap about half-past seven on the 22nd of Jan.—he gave me thif paper while the prisoner was in my office—I do not know the prisoner's hand
writing.

FREDERICK RUSSELL (City police-constable, No. 203.) I was sent for, and took the prisoner—I found this paper on him, on which, in pencil, were these words, "Wni. Holmes, 11, Wellington-street, Camden-town, clear the lot away as soon as possible, there is a move; I look up."

ROBERT EDWARD SIMPKINS . I accompanied the prisoner on the 22nd of Jan. with the parcels from the Birmingham Railway to go about town with them—there was a box for Roberts, Smith, and Co.—we got to Northumber
land-house, and delivered four boxes—we then went to Broadway, Westminster, where we had six bags of nails to deliver—on my return I did not notice whether the box was in the van—when we got into the Strand the prisoner said, "Oh, my God, Teddy, the box is gone"—we went to the Hampstead-road before that, and met Holmes the cabman—the prisoner went into the public-house with Holmes, and I was on the van waiting on the other side the road—he was there twenty minutes—the prisoner then came to the van and drove off—I knew Holmes by sight—I did not know where he lived—the prisoner told me his name was Holmes—when we got to the Castle and Falcon my master sent for me and talked to me about the matter—I told him we went to the public-house and met Holmes—the prisoner said we had met a man—I was absent from the cart at Westminster while I was delivering the parcel and getting my book signed for it—that would afford a man the oppor
tunity of taking the box—when we were in the Hampstead-road that morn
ing and met Holmes, I asked the prisoner if that was not the man we met in the Minories some time before—he said, "No, that man is dead and buried"—the box could not have tumbled off.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it not on the roof of the cart? A. No—in the middle of the van, on the two rails—there was a box or two underneath it—it was between nine and ten o'clock when we met Holmes—we got to the Broadway between two and three o'clock—I left the cart long enough for any person to take the goods away—when I was in the Broadway the prisoner turned the cart to a public-house, and I could not see it.
MR. CLARKBON. Q. When you went to take the nails, who did you leave in the cart? A. The prisoner.

JAMES BRISTOW COOPER , cook, Crouch-end, Paddington. On the 22nd Jan. I was out of employ—in the evening the prisoner came into the tap-room of the Castle and Falcon and asked for pen, ink, and paper—a female gave him pen and ink, but said she had no paper—I offered to give him a piece of paper—I tore it off the back of a letter and gave it him—he wrote upon it, folded it up, wafered it, and gave it to me, and said, "Cooper, you take that directly for me, I will give you 1s., for your trouble in the morning"—before I went I heard of this loss—in consequence of that I gave this paper to Mr. Alexander—I did not take notice of the prisoner's writing—I saw him fold it up and direct it—this is it—it is written on the back of a letter addressed to Mr. Cooper, Castle and Falcon.

FREDERICK RUSSELL
re-examined. I took the prisoner, and read this paper—I went to Wellington-street the same night—I there took Holmes, but the Magistrate discharged him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you say anything as to whether it would be better for him to tell you? A. No—I did not say "It is a pity you have not told your master all about it"—we have got the box.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What was it he said to you? A. In going through the hospital, he asked me if I thought he should be transported—I said, "I know nothing at all about it, but don't you think you had better tell your master the truth?"—he said he met Holmes and a man named Jack in Hamp
stead-road; as he was coming down the road they stopped him, and told him they should like to have one of the boxes in the van; he said he did not know what to say to that; they told him, if he would let them have one, there would be a good booty of it coming to him, and when he came to West
minster the box went away, but he could not tell whether it was Holmes or

this man Jack—I asked who he was—he said a man who was to be seen in all parts of London as porter, he did not know any more of him—I asked where they were to bring his share to—he said to the Castle and Falcon.
CHARTES JAMES MOATE . I am clerk to Roberts, Smith, and Co. This parcel did not arrive at our premises.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

750.
WILLIAM ALDERSON was indicted
for stealing 71bs. weight of bacon, value 3s. 9d., the goods of
Daniel Arthur Sykes.

DANIEL ARTHUR SYKES . I live in New-end, Hampstead-lane. On the 7th of Feb. I saw the prisoner in my shop—he took a piece of bacon off the counter, and threw it to a person at the door—I came into the shop—he asked for a pennyworth of tobacco—I asked what he had done with the bacon—he denied taking it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

751.
SAMUEL MULLETT was indicted
for stealing 6 jugs, value 3s.; 14 cups, 5s.; 17 saucers, 3s.; 6 cruets and tops, 10s.; 4 chimney ornaments, 15s.; 5 basins, 1s.; 2 milk-pots, 1s. 6d.; 1 tea-pot, 2s.; 6 plates, 3s.; 1 basket 1s.; and 2 twopenny pieces; the property of
Samuel Smith.

SAMUEL SMITH . I am an omnibus proprietor, and lodge at the King's Arms, Fulham; I formerly kept it. I first knew the prisoner as a waterman—I know the members of the Association at Fulham, and recommended him to them as a conductor—on the 10th of Nov. he was at my house—Mr. Webb came down from the meeting—a quarrel took place between the prisoner and Webb—he used very bad language, and I said it did not become him, he was getting a living under us—my wife was in the bar; she interfered in the quarrel; I told her it was no business whatever of hers, gave her a brush with my band, and said, "Go along"—a summons was taken out against roe on Monday, and Iappear—on the Saturday I received information; on Sunday morning I went to my drawers, and found they had been stripped of their contents—I made my wife put on her things, and leave the house—she went across to the prisoner's father's—I went to my drawers, and found the whole of their contents gone—in the room where my wife was I found a large portmanteau belonging to the prisoner, nailed and corded, in readiness to be removed—I did not allow them to be moved away—my wife never returned home—on the Tuesday I went with the constable to Mr. Gray's, in Drummond-street, at five in the morning, and in the back room, first floor, we found the prisoner and my wife in bed together—I gave them into custody, and they were taken to the station in Albany-street—they were discharged at the station—I afterwards followed them to Ireland, and gave them into custody—I went to where they lived in Ireland, and found six jugs, fourteen cups, seventeen saucers, six cruets and tops, four chimney ornaments, and other things, in a basket, and two twopenny-pieces in the prisoner's box—they are all my property, and the prisoner had seen them used at my house.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. What were you originally? A. I was driving at Clapham before I took the house at Fulham—I was an om
nibus conductor for a very short time—when the quarrel took place between the prisoner and Webb, I did not knock my wife down—she did not stagger with the blow—I will swear that I did not strike her a violent blow—the only part that I struck her was my nail was rather long, and cut the corner of her eye—I do not know whether it bled—we had a slight quarrel once, and I threw

my hat at her—I never remember kicking her—I never did to my knowledge—I have never had my lip cut by a woman since I have been married—the-only time I was away from my wife was three or four days, while I had a Wands
worth omnibus—I was lodging at Wandsworth, not with a female—I have never been intimate with another female since I have been married—I have not been in the habit of gambling—the only gambling I ever transacted was in the house which I used to keep, where it was usual for us to play at 3d. a corner, and sometimes 6d. or 1s.—I know a man named Hartly—I swear that the extent of my gambling has been 1s. 6d.—I never won in one nigbt at my house upwards of 30l.; nor any such sum—Hartly has a situation in a banking-house—there was no raffle in my house for a horse—there was at Mr. Hartly's house—I met Mr. Briant that night at Mr. Hardly's house—I and Briant did not divide between us what we had won that night—I cannot say whether I and Briant won that night—I made some little bets, but I cannot say whether I was a winner or loser—I did not pretend that night to lose 6l.; to Hartly—I do not think I lost 1l.;—I have not boasted in my own parlour how I and Briant had nailed Hartly—the card-playing went on in the back-parlour—we never went into a private room up stairs—it was a regular thing every night in the back parlour—it might go on up stain in private—my wife has not remonstrated with me, and told me I should ruin her, and that I was killing her by inches, in keeping her up—she has remon
strated with me when we have been later than usual of a night—I do not remember when I was gaming in the middle of the day my wife wanting to put the table-cloth on for dinner, and my laying hold of the table-cloth and kicking her—Warboys came to me at Wandsworth, to persuade me to come home to my wife—I am sure he has only done that once—I have not been away from her more than once, only the last time I was at Margate for ill health, when the prisoner was sleeping in my bed—I wished my wife to go down—she would not—Mr. Warboys offered to mind the house for my wife, if she would go—I first saw this portmanteau on Sunday morning—this basket was found at Dublin, but I saw a basket on the Tuesday, where these things were kept—the prisoner was in the house when I found this crockery—I claimed it then—my wife said, "There is nothing else be
longing to you"—I identified it, and pulled out two china greyhounds, which I identified—the policeman and Puddeford were there, they went to Ireland with me—I took them before a Magistrate in Ireland—upon my oath I then charged them with stealing this crockery—they were given to the officer to bring to England—the Irish Magistrate said he should have committed them if it had been his case—my wife purchased the crockery for the house—she did not bring me any property—after the death of her mother she brought me 400l.;—I gave my wife 80l.; or 90l.; to purchase things for the house—she purchased the things for my house—she superintended.

MILKS HURDNOT . I was formerly pot-boy to the prosecutor. On the Thursday before Mrs. Smith left I saw the prisoner, with a hamper in his hand, in the parlour, by the side of the gateway, at the back of the premises—he was packing the hamper with some cups and saucers—I do not know where they came from—I should not know them again—they were different to these—this hand-basket belonged to Mrs. Smith—I had seen both the baskets about the place—I had seen these baskets used by Smith—after the prisoner had packed up the things he told me to come in ten minutes, and when I went in ten minutes it was already corded—he lifted it on my back, and told me to take it to his father's back premises, and told me it was paint for his father—my master had gone up with the bust to London, and my mistress was in the parlour.
NOT GUILTY .

752.
SAMUEL MULLETT was again indicted
for stealing 1 penknife, value 1s. 6d.; 2 bags, 6d.; 1 purse, 1s. 6d.; 25 sovereigns, 19 half-crowns, 37 shillings, and 20 sixpences; the property of
Samuel Smith.

HANNAH SMITH . I am the prosecutor's wife, and was found in Drum
mond-street with the prisoner—before I left my husband I had some silver, partly new silver, which was kept in my bed-room—part of it accompanied us to Ireland—I fetched the money out of my bed-room about five months before I left home—I said I had no money—the prisoner said, "Yes, you have"—I said, "I have some up stairs, but I cannot let you have it"—he said, "Fetch it down"—I fetched it, and placed it in the bar drawer, telling him at the same time not to touch it for God's sake, for fear Smith should find it out—(I surrendered my person to the prisoner about two years before)—he said, "D—d nonsense"—he took the money way—I do not know what he did with it—to the best of my recollection there was 10l.; or 11l.;—I am not certain—he had it in his possession in Ireland in the bag—the bag bore some initials—I cannot say what they were—I went to Drummond-street on the Sunday—my husband turned me out from home—the prisoner had the money in his possession in Drum mond-street—my husband came and found us together—the money was then found in the prisoner's box—I saw it pro
duced—the prisoner claimed it—I am sure that was the money I brought down stairs—there were twenty-nine sovereigns in a white purse—the purse was the prisoner's, but the money was mine—he claimed it—he put them in some time before, because I was in the habit of giving him money—he promised if I got a certain quantity of money he would take me to Ireland—he took the silver out of the drawer, and I gave him the gold at home at our house.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Did your husband turn you out of the house? A. Yes; he told me to go out—he did once beat me—we never had any quarrels until I became acquainted with the prisoner—my husband has frequently beaten me—he never kicked me—I have been living with my sister in the Borough—my husband has not visited me there—he has been to the house—I have seen him, but he has not seen me—he has seen the child—Icame here on my own account—I met Mr. Warboys here, a friend of my husband's—I was not here yesterday, or the day before—I was here the beginning of last week—I came in case I should be wanted—no one told me I might be wanted—I volunteered my evidence here—I said when I was in Dublin that all the property was my own, and the prisoner knew nothing about it, that I was turned out, and sought protection from him, and he gave me that protection, that I sold him the knife found in his pocket for a half-penny, and he had committed no robbery, that it was me who got him into trouble, and I deemed it my duty to try and get him out, but I did it by the prisoner's persuasion—I fetched the silver down because he wished me—my husband allowed me to take it—I am not aware that I stated in Dublin that nothing occurred between me and the prisoner till my husband turned me out—upon my oath I did not say so—I know Mr. Jennings, the attorney—I told him that every shilling of the money I had given to the prisoner, but I said it by the prisoner's persuasion—my sister has been supporting me—she keeps the Black Bull in the Borough—I have not told any one what I had to say to-day—this purse I bought with my own money and gave to the prisoner.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did the prisoner know whose knife it was? A. He knew it was mine—Mr. Jennings came to me at Hammersmith, and I told him I had been very indifferently used by my husband at different times, and I was then going as evidence for the prisoner—I was not examined as a wit
ness—the prisoner told me to be sure and stick to what I said, and I pro
mised
I would—the money I gave him was my husband's—I had none of my own—I had had connexion with the prisoner before I gate him toe money.

WILLIAM THORNTON . I was horse-keeper to the prosecutor in Aug. and Sept.—I was at Fulham on a Wednesday when my matter was absent—I saw the prisoner at the house just before twelve o'clock—Mrs. Smith was up—no one else was in the house—I was in the tap-room, and Mrs. Smith told me it was time to go to bed—I went up stairs to go to bed in my room-after I went up stairs the prisoner followed Mrs. Smith up stairs to her bedroom—I saw Mrs. Smith draw the curtains and put out the light.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you never said one word about this to any one till two days after Mrs. Smith left? A. No.

JAMES GRAY , tobacconist, Drunmond-street, Euston-square. On Sunday, the 12th of Nov., the prisoner came to my bouse with Mrs. Smith—they asked for apartments for a few nights—I let them the first floor—they lived there as man and wife—they were found in bed at my house, by the officer snd Mr. Smith, at five o'clock in the morning—tbe prisoner brought three packages, which were directed to some person in Dublin—they returned to my house the same day as they were taken in custody, and left in half or three quarters of an hour—there was a hamper there, which was taken away to Liverpool, to be forwarded to Dublin.
Cross-examined. Q. Mrs. Smith was very fond of the prisoner? A. Yes.

EDWARD BROWN . I am a cabman, and stand in the rank in Drummond-street—on Sunday evening, the 12th of Nov., the prisoner came and asked if I could drive to Fulham—I said, "Yes"—he said he wanted some luggage brought back—I drove him to Fulham—he went to a house—he put a hamper and portmanteau, a canvas bag, a gun-case, and a deal box in the cab—he told me to drive on about twenty yards from the house, and he would come to me—he came, and told me to make the best of my way home to where I came from, which was Mr. Gray's house in Drummond-street—next day I went again with him to Fulham, and set him down about 200 yards before he got to his father's house—he told me to pull down to the door and bring the baggage away—I received from him a large chest and a hat-box—he ordered me to drive back, and stop at the same place that I had come. from—I said, "Yes," and he told me to take the left-hand road—I left him at Gray's.

SAMUEL SMITH . I remember my wife leaving home by my direction—I had before that deposited with her some silver; I cannot say what amount—I should think from the appearance of the bag, the last time I saw it, there must have been 7l.; or 8l.;—this is the bag—this shilling I can speak to—I was not aware that at any time before this my wife had parted with any of this money to the prisoner—I traced them to Drummond-street, and the prisoner took this bag out of his box—there was another little bag in this bag—it was my habit to trust my wife with the care of the money—when I got to Drummond-street I saw this bag, and said I had no doubt of its being mine, but I was in such an agitated state that I hardly remember what did transpire—I do not know what has become of the little bag—it was given up to the prisoner, he claiming it—my initials were on it—it was the bag that I had had in my house, and had delivered to my wife to take care of my money in—I have been missing money for a length of time, and complaining of it—I expected to find 200l.; in the house, which I did not—the prisoner
said the money was his.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know this shilling? A. From the diff
erent appearance and feel of it—I did not take it away in my pocket—it was

handed to me to identify, and I produced it from my pocket—the Magistrate told me to give it up to the officer—I might have given my wife a slap on the face several times, but not to have done her injury—the prisoner has been separated from his wife.

SAMUEL PUDDIFORD (police-constable T 127.) I went to Dublin with Mr. Smith—I had a warrant against the prisoner for deserting his wife and chil
dren—I did not know his wife—I found this bag of silver money in the bot
tom of the prisoner's box in Ireland—he told me it was his box.
Cross-examined. Q. Who obtained the parish warrant? A. It was given by the Magistrate—I do not know who applied for it—Mr. Inspector Smith gave itine.

SAMUEL SMITH
re-examined. This purse I found in Drummond-street, under the prisoner's pillow—he snatched at it, and said, "They are mine"—I said, "No, that one belongs to me, I know; I have carried money in it some time "—he threw it down—there were 14s. or 15s. in it—I took it and kept it—there was some gold in another under his pillow—from the appearance there must have been 30l.; in it—the prisoner claimed it, and it was restored to him.

HANNAH SMITH
re-examined. This purse I bought with my own money of the prisoner some time ago for 1s.—I afterwards gave it to my husband, and I took it from my home when I left.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi:
Fifth Jury, before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
753.
EMMA LEA was indicted
for stealing one shawl, value 10s., the goods of
Henry Joseph Fitzgerald; and 1 petticoat, value 5s., the goods of
Helen Bruce Graville.

HELEN BRUCE FITZGERALD . I am the wife of Henry Joseph Fitzgerald. On the 25th of Dec. we went to lodge at Mrs. Harper's, in Howland-street—my mother, Helen Bruce Graville, lodged with us—I lost a shawl—this is it—this petticoat I cannot swear to.
EDWARD ROFPEY . I am in the employ of a pawnbroker in Wardour-street I produce this shawl—I do not know who pawned it, but I gave this duplicate for it on the 19th of Jan.
HONORA CONNOLLY . I searched the prisoner at the station—she took off this petticoat, and said it was the petticoat that was missed.

GEORGE BOARDMAN , (police-constable E 46.) I received information last Monday, and went to Union-street, Middlesex Hospital, where I found the prisoner—I said I wanted her for stealing a shawl and a petticoat—she said she had taken the shawl, and gave me the duplicate of it.
CHARLOTTE HARPER . The prosecutrix lodged with me—the prisoner came to my house on the 24th of Dec. and left on the 26th.

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

754.
FREDERICK TIEDIMAN and
CHARLES WHEELER were in
dicted for
stealing 10 paving-stones, value 5s.; 10 other stones, value 5s.; 10 flags, value 5s.; and 10 feet of stone, value 5s.; the goods of the
Com
missioners for carrying into execution certain Acts of Parliament.—Other COUNTS, stating them to belong to other persons.

WILLIAM WELSH . I am a goldsmith, and live in Baker's-row, Clerkenwell. During the last month, the paving was being taken up in that row—on the 23rd of Jan. I saw Tiediman there between five and six o'clock in the even
ing—it was dusk, and he put some of the stones into a truck—after the truck was loaded, there was some one drawing it in front—I did not see Wheeler at

that time—I followed the truck, and Tiediman walked at a distance behind it—it went to a chandler's shop, No. 24, Easton-street—I saw Tiediman un
load the stones, and take them in there—I gave information to the constable.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. These were old stones that had been taken up? A. I believe they were—they were lying in the middle of the street in heaps—they were not fit to use in roads, but for the foot-path—they were not broken—the pavement was up at that time about my door.

ARTHUR KEEFE . I live in St. Helena-place, Clerken well. I was employed by Mr. Stile's to repair the pavement in Baker's-row—on the 23rd of Jan. I was in Baker's-row, between five and six o'clock—Wheeler and another person brought a truck—Tiediman and Wheeler put some old paving
stones into the truck, and took it away—Tiediman ordered me to help to shove the truck up, and I did as far as No. 24, Easton-street—I had not known Wheeler before—we took the stones into the house—I did not get any thing for the job—we had a pint of beer between us.

Q. Did your master tell you where to take the stones? A. Yes, to the greenyard—that is where all the old stones are taken—I did not know when Tiediman asked me to shove where they were going to—I knew that Easton-street was not the greenyard—I saw nine or ten stones at the station—I believe they were some that had been taken from Baker's-row.

CHARLES WAUGH , butcher, Guildford-street, Clerkenwell—Wheeler is a bricklayer, and sometimes does jobs in the paving-line—on Tuesday after
noon, the 23rd of Jan., he came to me about the job of repairing my yard in Easton-street—he said he had bought some stones, and they came to 8s. 4 1/2 d. and he had not got the money—I gave him 8s. 6d.,—I did not know they came from Baker's-row.

GEORGE ANDREWS (police-constable G 66.) On the 24th of Jan.
